{"position": null, "sentence": "Select, with its difficulties in animating had low agreement and high spread of proposals  (\ud835\udc9e\ud835\udc9f\u211b, \u2133\ud835\udc9e_select=.55, 21%).      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Speech from the multimodal gesture and speech block   A chi-square test of independence showed that there was a significant association between the block and syntax choice (X^2 (4, N=408)=10.928, p<0.03", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "10.928", "N": "408", "pval": "0.03", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Whereas, while cognitive forcing functions improved low NFC participants' carb source detection performance significantly on incorrect model predictions, they did not significantly improve their overall performance.       Detailed analysis of decisions when model predictions were incorrect.   For high NFC participants, consistent with the main findings, distributions of overreliance, human error, and correctness were significantly different between the CFF and SXAI categories for both the overall performance (\u03c7^2(2, N=357) = 13.12, p = .001", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "13.12", "N": "357", "pval": ".001", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "More participants diversified the background in their teaching set on the first attempt than the second (\u03c7^2(1, N=100)=4.35, p=.037", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "4.35", "N": "100", "pval": ".037", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "There were no significant differences within categories.        Detailed analysis of decisions when model predictions were incorrect.  On incorrect model predictions, participants could either follow the incorrect AI suggestion (i.e., overrely), provide a different incorrect answer (i.e., human error), or provide a correct answer.   Distributions of overreliance, human error, and correctness were significantly different across categories for overall performance (\u03c7^2(2, N=663) = 13.30, p = .0013", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "13.30", "N": "663", "pval": ".0013", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "We perform an 18-sample test for equality of proportions of accuracy \u223c{base_visualization} X {interaction_technique} with the null hypothesis that there are no differences in proportions of correct answers.   Within the high spatial ability group we find no significant differences ( RPLUS MATCH ), and therefore fail to reject the null hypothesis.   Within the low spatial ability group we again find no significant differences (\u03c7^2(17, N = 1092) = 23.41, p = 0.14", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "23.41", "N": "1092", "pval": "0.14", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "We find a statistically significant difference in accuracy between participants who did and did not interact with the cbAll visualization  (\u03c7^2(1, N = 246) = 21.63, p < 0.001", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "21.63", "N": "246", "pval": "0.001", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "For example, they were trendingly more likely to identify and compare the counties included in the redesigned chart, (\u03c7^2(1,  N = 54) = 5.33, p = 0.083", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "5.33", "N": "54", "pval": "0.083", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Our findings show that observing simultaneously two projects lowered the percentage of selecting high treatment condition projects in experiment 2 (52.4%) compared to experiment 1 (56.5%) across all project categories (\u03c7^2(1,N=1197) = 11.97, p<0.01", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "11.97", "N": "1197", "pval": "0.01", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "They simply re-opened it which resulted in a savings of Spack dependency resolution time, graph rendering time, and possible memory effects.       ASCII Visualizations Resulted in More Errors. {"position": null, "sentence": "Results from the descriptive analysis capture several systematic tendencies of the responses, which we detail below.      \u00a7.\u00a7 Influences from the Cultural Background   Students with a cultural background from social sciences differed significantly from students with a cultural background from computer science. `Social sciences' students were significantly more prone than computer science students to describe their choices matching the rationale `balance' from Section\u00a0<ref>.<ref>, whereas computer science students were significantly more prone than `Social sciences' students to describe their choices matching the rationale `algorithm' from Section\u00a0<ref>.<ref>: X^2(1,N=71)=8.1686, p<.05", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "8.1686", "N": "71", "pval": ".05", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Compared to the baseline and the original avatar, our proposed approach was selected most frequently overall  (\u03c7^2 (2, N = 3600) = 52.3, p < 0.01", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "52.3", "N": "3600", "pval": "0.01", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "There was a significant main effect of robot affect on post-task participant valence, \u03c7^2(1, N = 40) = 4.36, p = 0.037", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "4.36", "N": "40", "pval": "0.037", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Particularly they express support more frequently to the candidate themselves\u00a0(\u03c7^2(1, N=690)=6.31, p < 0.05", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "6.31", "N": "690", "pval": "0.05", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Overall, participants preferred an orthographic projection strategy (94.4%).    Border: There was a significant effect of border on projection strategy (\u03c7^2(1, N = 288) = 7.36, p < .01", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "7.36", "N": "288", "pval": ".01", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "On the other hand, others (5%) wished to avoid showing and discussing such conditions and regions with a doctor in person.      When asked I would trust a diagnosis based on medical photos from..., a \u03c7^2 test of independence revealed that respondents have higher trust in a diagnosis by a doctor (69.5% agree or strongly agree) compared to an AI-based diagnosis (23% agree or strongly agree), \u03c7^2 (4, N = 99) = 63.67, p < .001", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "63.67", "N": "99", "pval": ".001", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Namely, participants who viewed the original chart were significantly more likely than those who viewed the redesign to correctly describe the trend of immigration as increasing (\u03c7^2(1,  N=51) = 10.23, p = 0.007", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "10.23", "N": "51", "pval": "0.007", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "In other words, we are not just comparing the groups' overall activities, we are directly comparing \u201cclean\u201d and \u201cadversarial\u201d tweets made by each group, showing the differences in types even within these categories.  Figure\u00a0<ref>a shows the manually-labeled categories assigned to the users' tweets.  It is clear that the users in U_adv are more likely to engage in personal attacks against candidates (leftmost bar, \u03c7^2(1,N=690)=6.25, p < 0.05", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "6.25", "N": "690", "pval": "0.05", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "For analyzing the completion time, we applied a two-way repeated measures ANOVA.          \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Error Distance  There was an overall significant effect of projection strategy on error distance ( RPLUS MATCH ).  Post-hoc tests revealed that error distance was significantly lower for the orthographic projection strategy  (78.3 px) compared to the radial projection strategy (183.4px,p<.001).  Border: There was an overall significant effect of border on error distance for both the orthographic projection strategy ( RPLUS MATCH ) and the radial projection strategy ( RPLUS MATCH ).  Post-hoc tests revealed that error distance was significantly lower for the adaptive border (orthographic: 69.5 px, radial: 177.9 px) compared to the fixed border (orthographic: 87.0 px, radial: 188.9 px;p<.05).  Pointing Hub: There was an overall significant effect of pointing hub on error distance for both the orthographic projection strategy ( RPLUS MATCH ) and the radial projection strategy (\u03c7^2(1, N = 288) = 18, p < .001", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "18", "N": "288", "pval": ".001", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "Surprisingly, participants were as likely to use this argument when viewing the original as the redesigned chart (\u03c7^2(1,  N=44) = 2.32, p = 0.76", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "2.32", "N": "44", "pval": "0.76", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "After being shown each image, participants were asked the following question:                    Do you think the image should look more realistic or more artistic?     During the study, we logged the photos shown including the photo category, style weights and user critiques.   Each experiment lasted a total of \u223c3 minutes.             \u00a7.\u00a7 Participants   We recruited 31 participants from the Faculty of Science by walking up to people in the corridors of the Department of Computer Science and the Department of Mathematics and Statistics  (10 female, 21 male).  All participants were PhD students or postdoctoral researchers.     \u00a7.\u00a7 Results   The 31 participants examined a total of 310 photos: 95 head shots, 117 waist-up shots and 98 full body shots.       \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Baseline:    There are no validated questionnaires for rating image stylization and  pairwise comparisons between all images using all  models would require an impractical sample size.  Instead, we used a pre-trained model included in the PyTorch distribution  as a baseline to understand whether  the developer's original parameterization was sufficient to solve this problem.  The pre-trained model used a content weight of 10^5 (the same as our models) and a style weight of 10^10.      \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Preference Models:   We fitted two preference-based models using collective criticism.   In the first model, each study participant was modeled as a random effect (due to repeated measures) and photo type (head, waist-up or full body) was modeled as a fixed effect:       y_ij = \u03b2_0 + \u03b2_1p_ij + u_j,   where y are intervals derived from critiques, p is the photo type and u are random intercepts per user, j.  The second model was identical to the first, but with the photo type term excluded:       y_ij = \u03b2_0 + u_j     The style weights from the first model (log_10) for  head (M = 9.71, 95% CI [9.46, 9.95]), waist-up, (M = 9.53, 95% CI [9.31, 9.75]) and body shots (M = 9.39, 95% CI [9.14, 9.63])  were very similar to one another with overlapping 95% confidence intervals.  Indeed, the difference in model fit between the two models  was not statistically significant (\u03c7^2 (1.55, N = 310) = 3.14, p = 0.14", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "3.14", "N": "310", "pval": "0.14", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "The preferences of participant P2 are significantly dependent on the social role \u2013  RPLUS MATCH  and \u03c7^2(1, N = 1) = 100.76, p < 0.01", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "100.76", "N": "1", "pval": "0.01", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

Post-hoc tests revealed that error distance was significantly lower for the orthographic projection strategy  (78.3 px) compared to the radial projection strategy (183.4px,p<.001).  Border: There was an overall significant effect of border on error distance for both the orthographic projection strategy (\u03c7^2(1, N = 288) = 5.6, p < .05", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "5.6", "N": "288", "pval": ".05", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "An unpooled t-test on log error found a significant effect of mark  RPLUS MATCH e^-7)  with an effect size of 0.404\u2014this is equivalent to \u223c32% difference in absolute error.  These results are consistent with gestalt theory\u00a0<cit.> which predicts that color  is easier to perceive than shape due to \u201cpop-out\u201d than shape (Figure\u00a0<ref>).          We then fit the log-linear model to gauge how the accuracy depends on the input parameters. {"position": null, "sentence": "And that for people with low spatial ability, adding interaction to a static visualization does not significantly effect reasoning accuracy.                                                 \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Does underlying static visualization design moderate the effect of interaction techniques within spatial ability groups?   Within each spatial ability group we compare participants' accuracy across bases by performing a 3-sample test for equality of proportions of accuracy \u223c base_visualization, with the null hypothesis that there are no differences in the proportions of correct answers.   Within the high spatial ability group we find no significant difference in accuracy by base (\u03c7^2(2, N = 1114) = 2.93, p = 0.23", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "2.93", "N": "1114", "pval": "0.23", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "The color marking exhibits a slightly stronger negative relationship with pos (\u03c7^2(1,N=759)=6.11, p=.01", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "6.11", "N": "759", "pval": ".01", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "These results serve as a validity check, suggesting that the encouraging commentary was perceived as positive and   and the discouraging commentary was perceived as negative.  We found a significant main effect of robot affect on participants' liking of the activity, \u03c7^2(1, N = 40) = 6.97, p = 0.008", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "6.97", "N": "40", "pval": "0.008", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

{"position": null, "sentence": "And that for people with low spatial ability, adding interaction to a static visualization does not significantly effect reasoning accuracy.                                                 \u00a7.\u00a7.\u00a7 Does underlying static visualization design moderate the effect of interaction techniques within spatial ability groups?   Within each spatial ability group we compare participants' accuracy across bases by performing a 3-sample test for equality of proportions of accuracy \u223c base_visualization, with the null hypothesis that there are no differences in the proportions of correct answers.   Within the high spatial ability group we find no significant difference in accuracy by base ( RPLUS MATCH ), and therefore fail to reject the null hypothesis.  Figure <ref> shows near equal proportions of participants with high spatial ability answering the Bayesian reasoning questions correctly across base visualizations.  Within the low spatial ability group we find a significant difference in accuracy by base (\u03c7^2(2, N = 1092) = 11.23, p < 0.005", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "11.23", "N": "1092", "pval": "0.005", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}

We found no effect of affect on prioritization between W components.              \u00a7.\u00a7 Analysis of Self Assessment Manikin   The questionnaire about perceptions of the robot was also analyzed.  Because the data were not normally distributed and the sample was small (n < 50), the non-parametric Wilcoxon/Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test for two samples was used to compare the two conditions for all variables.  The robot's expressive language significantly affected several measures of positive social assessments of the robot, including perceptions that the robot was encouraging,  RPLUS MATCH , optimistic,  RPLUS MATCH , and cheerful, \u03c7^2(1, N = 40) = 28.33, p < 0.0001", "statisticType": "cstest_apa", "record": {"X2val": "28.33", "N": "40", "pval": "0.0001", "V": null}, "aspect": null, "condition": null}
